issue.title: Htaccess corrupted on update

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: priority: high
labels.description: Issues which should be resolved as quickly as possible

labels.name: effort: [S]
labels.description: 1-2 days of estimated development time

labels.name: severity: critical
labels.description: Defect that prevents the testing/use of the software

issue.body:
A few customers report that on occasion, typically when updating, the htaccess file is regenerated with only with our rules and nothing else, creating 404 errors. 
It doesn't seem to happen every time and seems almost impossible to reproduce, yet we have several reports now. 
Is there anything we can do to make sure that at least the default WP rules are placed back into the file?
HS tags: `htaccess`, `update fail`, `error 404`
Intercom report: https://app.intercom.io/a/apps/llnz7wr8/inbox/inbox/46787/conversations/15589780670

comment.body: I don't know if it is related, but over the years I have had to click on "update permalinks" often when I update multiple plugins (WPML) and WP-Rocket. Before there are 404 issues and sometimes and empty store on the secondary language.

issue.title: WP Rocket Caching plugin gets disabled on code deployment.
issue.body:
Here's our setup: WP Rocket is working and caching pages on our site. If we make a code update to the site, the following things happen:

- The code is pulled from git into a temporary directory. The code coming from git includes the wp-content/wp-rocket-config/ directory. 
- Various changes are made to the temp dir: some directories are mounted in place and some files are changed depending on various environmental factors eg dev or live.
- In particular, the correct advanced-cache.php to match the environment is copied into the wp-content folder. 
- The old web root directory is moved out of the way and the new web-root directory is moved into place. 

After a code update WP rocket is no longer caching pages. In order to start it again, the plugin needs to be disabled and re-enabled, at which point cacheing will resume. 

Originally the setup was that the wp-content/cache directory was pulled from git, and therefore moreorless empty. 
We have also tried pointing the cache directory somewhere outside of the webroot using advanced-cache.php settings, so that it isn't emptied on a code update. This also causes cacheing to pause. 

Maybe this is expected behavior. But we'd like to find a way to deploy code that doesn't mean manually restarting the cache plugin.  Are there extra configuration files that we're not accounting for? Is there a workaround?

pull_request.title: Fixes #4226 bail-out if WP_IMPORTING is defined
pull_request.body:
## Description

Stop the plugin initialization if `WP_IMPORTING` is defined, to prevent issue with too much cache clearing with each post/page imported, especially when there is a lot to import.

Fixes #4226

issue.title: Conflict with Sirdata "data-cmp-src" attribute with Delay JS
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
When using scripts conditionned by sirdata CMP (replacement of <script src=""></script> by <script data-cmp-src=""></script>), WP Rocket replaces attribute by adding its "data-rocket-..." and ignoring the "data-cmp-" prefix.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to any editable content (template, widget...)
2. Add a conditionned script like <script data-cmp-src="https://www.googletagmanager.com/gtag/js"></script>
3. Activate WP Rocket Delay JS optimization, with or without exclusions
4. Check the generated html on public pages : there will be undesired "data-cmp-data-rocket-src" attributes, naturally ignored and scripts are not loaded

**Expected behavior**
data-cmp-src should not be replaced by data-cmp-data-rocket-src.

**Additional context**
Seen multiple times, and generally solved by adding "data-cmp-src" to exclusion list.
What would be really really nice is to be able to delay JS execution on this conditionned scripts too. But I think it's probably too specific to be prioritized in the roadmap.

**Acceptance Criteria (for WP Media team use only)**

issue.title: Load CSS Asynchronously - Update IPs in the warning notice
issue.body: **Before submitting an issue please check that you’ve completed the following steps:** - Made sure you’re on the latest version ✅ - Used the search feature to ensure that the bug hasn’t been reported before ✅ **Describe the bug** When IPs are not allowed by Cloudflare, WP Rocket displays a warning in the WP Rocket Settings Meta box at the page settings level: These IPs are out of date: https://docs.wp-rocket.me/article/1628-which-ip-do-i-need-to-allow-for-wp-rocket **Expected behavior** We should add a link to our doc instead of showing the IPs: https://docs.wp-rocket.me/article/1628-which-ip-do-i-need-to-allow-for-wp-rocket This should be the same for every notification where WP Rocket displays blocked IPs warning. **Acceptance Criteria (for WP Media team use only)** Clear instructions for developers, to be added before the grooming

review.body:
Working as expected with the following notes

Using WPML Dir setup and domain setup

1. Purge this URL while using WPML will purge only the specific language where we click purge
2. If we add a new post, it clears only the main language of home and when we add a translation to another language, then will clear the other language of home (only while permalinks with / )  
3. Clear this cache from the page list, will clear only the language matching the admin 
4. Deleting a post will only delete post/home for the language used in admin (related GH [6246](https://github.com/wp-media/wp-rocket/issues/6246)

[testrail-report-538.pdf](https://github.com/wp-media/wp-rocket/files/13175506/testrail-report-538.pdf)

issue.title: WPML: Partial cache clearing isnot working correctly when delete a post

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Improvements that slightly enhance existing functionality and are fast to implement

labels.name: 3rd party compatibility
labels.description: Issues related to 3rd party compatibility like theme, plugin or hosting

labels.name: priority: low
labels.description: Issues that can wait

issue.body:
**Before submitting an issue please check that you’ve completed the following steps:**
- Made sure you’re on the latest version =>3.15.3
- Used the search feature to ensure that the bug hasn’t been reported before

**Describe the bug**
When deleting a post, We are only cleaning the main language of that post and home and we are not removing the other languages

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. WPML directory setup or domain base setup
2. Preload is disabled
3. Cache home, home with cached qs, post, post with cached qs with all translations 
4. While admin is using the main language, delete the post => only the main language of home and posts with/without qs are removed from the cache folder

**Expected behavior**
Cache clear for home and post in all languages with/without qs

**Screenshots**
If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.
- If we add a post, only the main language of the home will be deleted but once adding translation for that post, the home translation will be deleted (same when editing) 
- Purge this URL and clear this cache will also clear only the language matching the admin language

**Acceptance Criteria (for WP Media team use only)**
Clear instructions for developers, to be added before the grooming
- When deleting/trash a post, we Shall  clear the cache of that post, home , prev/next with /without qs for all languages

issue.title: Deactivate Separate Cache for Mobile Devices when WP Rocket is used on hosts not supporting separate cache for mobile

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Improvements that slightly enhance existing functionality and are fast to implement

labels.name: priority: low
labels.description: Issues that can wait

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
When using WP Rocket on hosting service with caching layers not supporting mobile-specific cache, enabling the corresponding feature on WP Rocket will mislead the user to think the site is serving mobile-specific cache.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Graying the feature on hosts where we know for sure they don't support mobile-specific cache could be a good thing to consider.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
N/A 

**Additional context**
Ticket - https://secure.helpscout.net/conversation/1677829538/304267/

comment.body:
> Which hosts do you consider as not compatible "for sure" ?

For example, when using the rocket-nginx module. It's not compatible with this feature. Also, in my particular case, it's very annoying that the plugin is detecting that I've wpDiscuz installed and then it forces the separate cache for mobiles, and I do not want to use that, but there is no way to disable the switch. Isn't there any hook to force disable separate mobile cache from theme functions.php?

issue.title: RUCSS SASS user agent
issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Customers who are managing a large number of sites running WPR with a WAF enabled have to manually update all our IPs on each site each time they change.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Identify all requests from the RUCSS crawler with a dedicated user agent.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
From @DahmaniAdame: _We can't do the updates ourselves as last time some customers complained about allowing our IPs on Wordfence. It makes sense to make the IPs available and leave to the customer to do the updates themselves. Either as part of the dynamic lists or have an endpoint for that purpose._

**Additional context**
HS ticket: https://secure.helpscout.net/conversation/2399910452/450291
Slack thread: https://wp-media.slack.com/archives/C08N8J6VC/p1698236250084859

issue.title: Automatic backup of the settings before the update

labels.name: feature request
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
If an update causes any changes to the customers' settings, it would be great to have a backup of the old settings made automatically before the update.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
We could export the settings in JSON to `/wp-rocket-config/` directory before updating to the newer version.

**Additional context**
I thought about this due to the last, 3.7.6 update problem.

issue.title: Optimized fallback fonts not integrated within RUCSS rules

labels.name: needs: r&d
labels.description: Needs research and development (R&D) before a solution can be proposed and scoped.

comment.body:
@mostafa-hisham @piotrbak 
Hello, a fallback font is, by definition, not the used font.
But in the same time, this is exactly why it exists.

Like I said, it can be whitelisted manually but most users will forget it and won't even be able to see it.
But it will degrade web performance, especially the CLS metric.

Safelisting "-fallback" is not the way to go, this is a rule we are using at Agence Web Performance, but not a standard. It could potentially be any name.

The way to go is, in my opinion, to safelist the @font-face declarations for all the fonts declared in the font stacks.
Most of the time, only the first font will have ont, the others being safe fonts (Arial, Verdana...) or generic fonts like sans-serif.

Thanks.

issue.title: Preload - Re-fetch the sitemap in different scenarios

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Improvements that slightly enhance existing functionality and are fast to implement

labels.name: priority: low
labels.description: Issues that can wait

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

This is to discuss future enhancements of the Preload feature about cases where re-fetching the site's sitemap would offer an overall better experience with the feature.

1. There are occasions where we'll need to re-fetch the site's sitemap and preload any URLs that are there but are not in the `wpr_rocket_cache` table.

Currently, when removing exclusions from "Never Cache URLs" the "affected" URLs will be preloaded when they are accessed by visitors, i.e. they won't be preloaded. When using `(.*)` to exclude several URLs this has an even greater impact.

2. In cases, like the one in #5692, we would need to fetch the sitemap and remove the URLs that aren't there.

3. When sitemap-generating plugins, e.g. Yoast, regenerate the sitemap.

4. When adding/removing URLs to/from the preload exclusion text area.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

We could:
1. Re-scan the sitemap on specific occasions, e.g. when "Never Cache URLs" change.
3. Add missing URLs to the `wpr_rocket_cache` table. In cases such as #5692 we should remove the additional URLs and "ban" them from being preloaded.
5. Preload the missing URLs.


**Describe alternatives you've considered**

To avoid having to create plugin-specific compatibility, e.g. with Yoast, for re-fetching the sitemaps on specific occasions, we could run a cron job daily or weekly (this could be filterable) to fetch the sitemap. Then either add or remove URLs from the cache table.

comment.body: Sometimes re-fetching the sitemap after changing permalinks is not working. (needs further investigation with WP sitemap , home page URLs, SEO plugin, custom sitemap)

issue.title: RUCSS submitted_at field is incorrect

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: effort: [XS]
labels.description: < 1 day of estimated development time

issue.body:
Context
Follow-up on this https://github.com/wp-media/wp-rocket/issues/6204 which has a bug.
Submitted_at should be the timestamp at which we send the job to the SaaS. So, it should be set to null when putting the job in "to-submit" and set to current timestamp when putting the job "pending".

**Bug reproduction**
Start a lot of  RUCSS jobs from the plugin and limit the number of pending jobs to a small number. Some jobs will remain in to-submit for a while but they already have a submitted_at date.
**How to fix**
Set `submitted_at` to `null` in `create_new_job` and `reset_job`. Set it to current timestamp in `make_status_pending`

comment.body: @MathieuLamiot When retries change, Shall we update the submitted_at timestamp or it's just mapping the 1st request?

labels.name: type: enhancement

labels.name: 3rd party compatibility
labels.description: Issues related to 3rd party compatibility like theme, plugin or hosting

labels.name: priority: medium
labels.description: Issues which are important, but no one will go out of business.

issue.body:
**Before submitting an issue please check that you’ve completed the following steps:**
- Made sure you’re on the latest version
- Used the search feature to ensure that the bug hasn’t been reported before

**Describe the bug**
WPML Team reported that when translating a single post we're clearing the cache once per language. It's possible to do it only once to avoid resources problems.

**To Reproduce**
Included in https://github.com/wp-media/wp-rocket/issues/6214#issuecomment-1757574484

**Expected behavior**
Included in https://github.com/wp-media/wp-rocket/issues/6214#issuecomment-1757574484

**Acceptance Criteria (for WP Media team use only)**
- We should launch `rocket_clean_domain` only once, not once per language
- No regression at clearing the translated posts
- No regression at clearing the specific languages

comment.body:
### Scope a solution ✅ 
We can add a new filter outside of the loop `rocket_after_clean_domain`, and update the hook used in the preload subscriber (Could be also good to investigate other usages of the `after_rocket_clean_domain` filter to see if they could be changed and reduce the number of calls to the hooked methods).

### Estimate the effort ✅
Effort [S]

issue.title: RUCSS submitted_at field is incorrect
issue.body:
Context
Follow-up on this https://github.com/wp-media/wp-rocket/issues/6204 which has a bug.
Submitted_at should be the timestamp at which we send the job to the SaaS. So, it should be set to null when putting the job in "to-submit" and set to current timestamp when putting the job "pending".

**Bug reproduction**
Start a lot of  RUCSS jobs from the plugin and limit the number of pending jobs to a small number. Some jobs will remain in to-submit for a while but they already have a submitted_at date.
**How to fix**
Set `submitted_at` to `null` in `create_new_job` and `reset_job`. Set it to current timestamp in `make_status_pending`
